headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marsh & McLennan Companies Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Third quarter 2011 financial results and supplemental information were issued earlier this morning. They are available on Marsh & McLennan Companies website at www.
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marsh & McLennan Companies Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Third quarter 2011 financial results and supplemental information were issued earlier this morning. They are available on Marsh & McLennan Companies website at www.mmc.com.
Before we begin, I would like remind you that remarks made today may include statements relating to future events or results, which are forward-looking statements as that term is defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements are subject to inherent risks and uncertainties. In particular, references during this conference call to anticipated or expected results of operations for 2011 or subsequent periods are forward-looking statements, and Marsh & McLennan Companies' actual results may be affected by a variety of factors. Please refer to Marsh & McLennan Companies' most recent SEC filings, as well as the company's earnings release, which are available on the Marsh & McLennan Companies' website, for additional information on factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements made today. I'll now turn the conference over to Brian Duperreault, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Please go ahead.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our third quarter results as reported earlier today. I'm Brian Duperreault, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining me on the call today is Dan Glaser, Group President and COO; and Van
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our third quarter results as reported earlier today. I'm Brian Duperreault, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining me on the call today is Dan Glaser, Group President and COO; and Vanessa Wittman, our CFO. Also, I'd like to welcome our operating companies CEO, Peter Zaffino of Marsh; Alex Moczarski of Guy Carpenter; and John Drzik of Oliver Wyman. Also with us is Mike Bischoff. Following my comments, Dan will discuss our operating results in more detail, Vanessa will then update you on our financial position. 
Before we begin our discussions of the third quarter, I'd like to take a moment to recognize and thank Michele Burns for her many contributions to our company over the last 5 years. Michele became Mercer’s CEO in 2006 and led Mercer to a period of growth despite severe turbulence in the global economy. Last month, we announced that Michele has accepted a new role to build and lead a retirement policy center. I believe this center has potential of making a major contribution for finding solutions that address the retirement issues facing the United States. I'm excited that Michele has agreed to take on the challenge of leading this effort. We announced searching for a new CEO of Mercer and until the successor is named, Dan will be overseeing Mercer’s operations. 
Now let's move to our third quarter law results, which reflect our ongoing strong performance. We generated revenue growth of 11%. On an underlying basis, revenue growth was 5%, and we continue to achieve this growth while maintaining effective control over our operating expenses. This led to an increase in operating income of 30% and growth in adjusted operating income of 18%. 
Let's turn to our operating companies. The positive momentum at Marsh continued this quarter, with underlying revenue growth across all geographies driven by higher client revenue retention rates and new business development. Guy Carpenter also generated impressive results, continuing its trend of producing quarterly underlying revenue growth, which has expanded over the past 3 years. Mercer produced underlying revenue growth of mid-single digits as it has over the past years. Oliver Wyman's strong revenue growth continued reflecting broad-based growth across its major industry sectors. So throughout Marsh & McLennan Companies  we've seen revenue increases and higher levels of profitability. This record of performance is very much in keeping with the goals we articulated at Investor Day in September of 2010. It's not been more than a year since then, so I think it's appropriate to step back and look at the progress the company has made. We're implementing our plan to establish Marsh & McLennan Companies as an elite, global growth company, valued by clients, our colleagues and shareholders. We articulated the strategy of focusing on 4 pillars: growth and revenue and earnings per share, low capital requirements, high cash generation and reducing the risk profile of the company. 
As you look at our performance since Investor Day, the achievements are evident. Over the last 4 quarters, the company has produced underlying revenue growth of 5%, and I'm pleased that each of the operating companies contributed to that achievement. Marsh grew by 5%; Carpenter, 5%; Mercer, 4%; and Oliver Wyman grew 9%. Our goal is to produce underlying revenue growth, while maintaining expense discipline, thereby generating at least 10% organic growth and adjusted operating income over the long term. I'm pleased to report that we are achieving our goals. We have produced revenue growth across the entire enterprise. We have continued to make investments for future growth. And we've done this by limiting -- while limiting our adjusted underlying expense growth to 4%. As a result, I'm very pleased that over the last 4 quarters, Marsh & McLennan Companies generated organic growth and adjusted operating income of 13%, an outstanding performance. This earnings growth combined with our dividend yield of 3% is a very attractive result for our investors and in keeping with the goals we articulated at Investor Day more than a year ago. 
Additionally, we've continued to maintain low capital requirements and generated high levels of cash. Operational changes throughout the organization, we believe, have lowered the companies risk profile. Our financial position has strengthened during this period as well, which we'll discuss in a few minutes. As we move forward, we remain committed to focusing on profitable growth and prudent redeployment of our excess cash flow in order to produce outstanding long-term returns for our shareholders. With that, let me turn it over to Dan to review our third quarter results in more detail.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Marsh & McLennan Companies continued its strong performance in the third quarter. We generated underlying revenue growth that was consistent prior periods with impressive growth in both operating income and ad
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Marsh & McLennan Companies continued its strong performance in the third quarter. We generated underlying revenue growth that was consistent prior periods with impressive growth in both operating income and adjusted operating income. 
Let me go into a little more detail on our operating results. In the third quarter, we achieved revenue growth and increased adjusted operating income at each of our operating companies as we have for each quarter over the past year. In the quarter, revenue rose 11% to $2.8 billion, while underlying revenue growth was 5%. Adjusted operating income increased 18%. Risk and Insurance Services revenue was up 11% to $1.5 billion with underlying revenue growth of 5%. And with ongoing effective expense management, adjusted operating income increased 13% to $186 million. The adjusted operating margin increased 20 basis points, reflecting slightly higher margins at both of Marsh and Guy Carpenter. This is also indicative of the segment's performance year-to-date where the margin has increased to 19.5% despite the effects of higher pension expense. 
Marsh had another strong quarter. Revenue increased 12% to $1.2 billion. Underlying revenue rose 6%. Marsh's high client revenue retention rate and new business development produced underlying revenue growth across all geographies, led by strong growth in Asia-Pacific and Latin America of 13%. In the U.S. Canada division, underlying revenue growth was 3% for the fifth consecutive quarter. Marsh has maintained its disciplined expense control, while still being able to invest in the future, refine its operating model and absorb higher severance and pension expense. As a result, Marsh produced double-digit growth in adjusted operating income, not just for the quarter, but for the year-to-date as well. 
In August, we announced a significant expansion of our South African operations with the signing of an agreement to acquire the insurance broking business of Alexander Forbes. The transaction is scheduled to close by year end. 
Now turning to reinsurance broking. Guy Carpenter continued to produce strong results. Revenue increased 8% to $251 million with underlying growth of 3%. This growth was led by its international operations, reflecting the successful execution of its long-term business strategy. Over the last 3 years, Carpenter has consistently produced quarterly underlying revenue growth. It has been able to accomplish this through strong new business development and high client retention. So in summary, both March and Guy Carpenter produced strong financial results, not only in the third quarter but for the 9 months as well. 
Turning to our Consulting segment. Our operations continued to generate strong revenue growth. In the third quarter, revenue rose 11% to $1.3 billion with underlying growth of 6%. Growth in adjusted underlying expenses was 5%, which resulted in a 50 basis point increase in the adjusted operating margin for the quarter. Growth in adjusted operating income was 17%, not only for the third quarter but for the year as well with both Mercer and Oliver Wyman contributing to this strong growth. Mercer continued the solid performance we've seen over the past year. Revenue in the third quarter increased 11% to $975 million, and underlying revenue growth was 4% with all geographic regions contributing to this growth. Consistent with the revenue trends we've seen in Mercer’s line of business over the past year, retirements saw underlying revenue decline modestly. Health and Benefits had a fine performance with an underlying increase of 7%, driven by strong growth in the U.S. and Asia-Pacific. Rewards, Talent and Communications produced double-digit underlying revenue growth for the fifth consecutive quarter. Outsourcing generated underlying growth of 1%, reflecting growth in Asia-Pacific partially offset by a decline in the United States. And investment consulting management produced underlying growth of 10% with strong growth in the U.S. and EMEA. Oliver Wyman also had a good quarter with an increase in revenue of 13%. Underlying revenue growth was 9%. This growth was diversified with the strongest growth coming from the healthcare and consumer industry sectors. Oliver Wyman expense management also contributed to the solid increase in adjusted operating income. 
In summary, we are very pleased with the excellent performance of each of our operating companies, not only this quarter but throughout the entire year, both from a revenue and earnings growth standpoint. Now let me make several comments regarding how the increased economic uncertainty that developed in the summer, particularly in Europe may impact our near-term results. Oliver Wyman is our most economically sensitive operating company. We've seen some clients in the financial services sector defer decisions on new engagements, thus making it difficult for Oliver Wyman to generate growth in the fourth quarter resulting in a modest impact of the segments profitability. Currently, overall client interest remains high, and the pipeline going into 2012 looks encouraging. However, there is a high degree of uncertainty, so that's 0W. At Mercer, all signs indicate that the positive trends experienced in the first 9 months of the year are continuing, and we feel that any near-term economic uncertainty is not impacting our Risk and Insurance Services segment. So notwithstanding near-term economic issues, we believe we are on target to have a very successful year and remain optimistic as we develop our strategy and business plans for 2012. With that, let me turn it over to Vanessa.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan, and good morning, everyone. As you've heard, the strong financial performance of Marsh & McLennan Companies continued in the third quarter. On a GAAP basis, net income was $130 million or $0.24 per share. Adjusted earnings per share was al
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan, and good morning, everyone. As you've heard, the strong financial performance of Marsh & McLennan Companies continued in the third quarter. On a GAAP basis, net income was $130 million or $0.24 per share. Adjusted earnings per share was also $0.24. Costs of $72 million related to the early extinguishment of debt from the tender offer are highlighted on a separate line in this quarter's income statement. This expense is reflected in both our GAAP EPS and our adjusted EPS. I should also note that our a GAAP and adjusted earnings are almost identical for the 9-month period as well. Operating income totaled $1.247 billion, and adjusted operating income was $1.252 billion. As a result, GAAP earnings per share continuing operations year-to-date was $1.30, and adjusted earnings per share also totaled $1.30. 
Now let me add some color regarding other items, including our recent financing activities. In the third quarter, interest expense decreased to $49 million from $60 million a year ago. This level of quarterly interest expense is a reasonable indicator of the run rate we expect going forward. Several actions taken over the past 12 months substantially reduced our interest expense. First was the payment of a $550 million debt obligation in September 2010. Next, in July of this year, we took advantage of interest rate environment for a tender refinancing effort to  extend our majority of the latter and reduce our aggregate interest expense. We had $1.4 billion of debt coming due in 2014 and 2015, and we successfully tendered for $600 million of these bonds. We funded the tender with $ 100 million dollars of cash and a new 10-year note for $500 million with a coupon of 4.8%. We are very pleased with these transactions, which allowed us to opportunistically refine our capital structure, lower our refinancing risks in the intermediate term, extend maturities of our debt portfolio at a very attractive interest rate and delever our balance sheet. In total, the actions taken over the past year reduced our annual interest expense by $45 million. 
Turning to investment income, in the third quarter, investment income was essentially 0 compared with a $2 million loss in last year's third quarter. Due to a decline in the equity markets in the third quarter, we anticipate reporting an investment loss of approximately $10 million in the fourth quarter. 
Moving on to share repurchase. Since beginning our share repurchase program in last year's the fourth quarter, the company has repurchased a total of 15.6 million shares at a cost of $447 million, including 4.4 million shares that were purchased in the third quarter. In August, our Board of Directors authorized an increase in the share repurchase program to $1 billion from $500 million. 
Looking at taxes. Our adjusted tax rate this quarter increased to 32.7%. This compares with 30.4% in last year's third quarter. A drop in the U.K. statutory tax rate reduced the value of our U.K. net deferred tax assets, which was fully reflected this quarter. This change in the U.K. tax law put upward pressure on our adjusted tax rate in the third quarter but will slightly benefit our overall tax position going forward. The higher tax rate in the current quarter also reflects a slight shift in the geographic mix of earnings. While there may be volatility in our tax rate from quarter to quarter, we still feel that for modeling purposes, it is reasonable to assume a tax rate of approximately 31% over the next year. Due to our high cash generation, we were able to redeploy our cash in the third quarter in a number of ways, including a $126 million per share repurchase, $123 million for dividend, $100 million to reduce long-term debt, $72 million for the early debt repayment and $21 million for acquisitions. This effective redeployment of capital will also contribute to our future growth in earnings per share. And despite all of these actions, our cash position increased $55 million during the third quarter. Debt at the end of the third quarter was $2.9 billion. We have a $250 million note due March 15, 2012, which is our only debt coming due in 2012. Last month, we took advantage of favorable conditions in the credit market, and we're able to close a new $1 billion, 5-year revolving credit facility to replace our existing $1 billion, 3-year credit facility that was due to expire next year. We are very pleased with the increased financial flexibility and reduced uncertainty resulting from the new facilities extended duration. With that, I'll turn the call back to Brian.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and we're ready for your questions.
componenttext: Thank you, and we're ready for your questions.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Keith Walsh from Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Keith Walsh from Citi.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess first question for Dan, just around Consulting. When I think about your comments about Oliver Wyman going into the fourth quarter, maybe a little bit tougher it seems. Maybe you could talk about that in the context of the margin. It seems Oliver W
componenttext: I guess first question for Dan, just around Consulting. When I think about your comments about Oliver Wyman going into the fourth quarter, maybe a little bit tougher it seems. Maybe you could talk about that in the context of the margin. It seems Oliver Wyman probably has a lot higher margin with the revenue per head being I think double what Mercer is. And if you can kind of also talk in the broader context of just Mercer margins in general, what do you think you can take that to over the next couple of years? It seems your competitors have some much higher target out there although it seems to be going backwards at this point, but if you could talk about that.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I'll talk for a while, and then John will probably have some comments specific to Oliver Wyman. But in general, we don't disclose margins for individual operating companies. We talked about the segment overall, and so let me just start there. For both
componenttext: So I'll talk for a while, and then John will probably have some comments specific to Oliver Wyman. But in general, we don't disclose margins for individual operating companies. We talked about the segment overall, and so let me just start there. For both Oliver Wyman and Mercer, we believe that over time we will be able to expand the margins. So we're very much focused on creating the business disciplines that are necessary in order to be able to commit to that, so that's #1. I'll leave it to John in a second to talk about Oliver Wyman specifically and what he's seeing in the market. In terms of Mercer, I'd start by saying, Mercer is a really strong company. It's large. It's growing. It's globally coordinated. It's profitable. It's got some great people. It's got a great client list. So I spent a good part of my time in the last 5 months really digging into Mercer, and a lot of what I see, I'm pleased with. My goal is to work with Mercer leadership team to take all this and make it better. We can be more global, we can be more profitable with better margins and we be more innovative. And so that will be the focus of leadership team and I over the coming months and years.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So, Keith, just to expand a bit on what Dan said in his comments about Oliver Wyman. In August and September when we were in a period there of tightened economic uncertainty and more market volatility, it resulted in a slowdown in new sales for Oliver Wym
componenttext: So, Keith, just to expand a bit on what Dan said in his comments about Oliver Wyman. In August and September when we were in a period there of tightened economic uncertainty and more market volatility, it resulted in a slowdown in new sales for Oliver Wyman. While our third quarter results were strong with a 9% growth, that will impact our fourth quarter, and so fourth quarter will be weaker. And particularly, the financial services sector especially the banking sector is where we're experiencing the weakness. And as Dan said, it'll make Q4 challenging one for us. It'll be challenging for us to grow in Q4. Now looking at what recent events mean, in October, sales picked up to back to a normal pace as the market seems to stabilize. And client pipeline is encouraging at this point. events of this week suggest there could be an extended period of uncertainty. We could see that coming back in. So I think, looking at medium-term, I'd say we're very confident that Oliver Wyman is an attractive growth business and will generate margin growth, as Dan said, over that period. But quarter-to-quarter, we could fluctuate somewhat based on the economic outlook and uncertainty. And obviously, that's I think what we'll experience in the fourth quarter this year.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question is for Vanessa. Maybe if you could just remind us regarding pension expense, what was the change in the discount rate last year that led to the $12 million quarterly headwind we're seeing now?
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question is for Vanessa. Maybe if you could just remind us regarding pension expense, what was the change in the discount rate last year that led to the $12 million quarterly headwind we're seeing now?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Keith, last year, the aggregate -- remember, you got to look across both the U.S. and the U.K on a blended basis, it was about a 40 basis point change, but that's blended. And you've got plans in the U.S., U.K. and then the rest of the world where those a
componenttext: Keith, last year, the aggregate -- remember, you got to look across both the U.S. and the U.K on a blended basis, it was about a 40 basis point change, but that's blended. And you've got plans in the U.S., U.K. and then the rest of the world where those are individual accounts. And that would've led to our change, which has been about a $12 million per quarter impact over the course of the year.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just taking that, you got about 50 basis point discount rate reduction year-to-date. We're looking at in both the U.S. and the U.K. I would assume the impact for 2012 potentially similar magnitude both...
componenttext: Just taking that, you got about 50 basis point discount rate reduction year-to-date. We're looking at in both the U.S. and the U.K. I would assume the impact for 2012 potentially similar magnitude both...

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we have said in the past, I know it's tempting at this point in the year and with the volatility that we see in the market for us to make a call and give you a prediction. But as we've also done in the past, we're not going to give you a prediction. We
componenttext: As we have said in the past, I know it's tempting at this point in the year and with the volatility that we see in the market for us to make a call and give you a prediction. But as we've also done in the past, we're not going to give you a prediction. We are very keenly focused on the changes, but it's just not right for a public dialogue. And what you can count on, Keith, is as we've done to date, we're watching it, we're monitoring it and we'll continue to manage the business through next year to deliver on our commitments to our shareholders.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we will take our next question from Brian Meredith from UBS.
componenttext: Moving on, we will take our next question from Brian Meredith from UBS.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two questions here. First, Vanessa, I wondered what the cash position right now? Is it possible to give us a sense of what's U.S. versus international? And basically what I'm trying to get at is, how much cash is going to be available right now for repurc
componenttext: Two questions here. First, Vanessa, I wondered what the cash position right now? Is it possible to give us a sense of what's U.S. versus international? And basically what I'm trying to get at is, how much cash is going to be available right now for repurchases?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me take that 2 ways. The first is that we don't break out our U.S. and international cash. But I think that from our profitability, you could probably safely assume that the bulk of that cash is offshore. And from a repurchase estimation perspective,
componenttext: Let me take that 2 ways. The first is that we don't break out our U.S. and international cash. But I think that from our profitability, you could probably safely assume that the bulk of that cash is offshore. And from a repurchase estimation perspective, we've been pretty consistent in saying that our number one priority is investing in the business with one, doing accretive acquisition. So as you're looking out over the course of the year, we've committed to absorbing in our repurchase what we are issuing from an equity perspective to our colleagues. But I think you should count on the accretive acquisitions and investments in the business first. And we do have an acquisition in the fourth quarter that we expect to close of the bulk of that Alexander Forbes acquisition.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then second question, Dan and Peter, I wonder if you could elaborate a little bit on the rate environment out there right now what you are all seeing?
componenttext: Great. And then second question, Dan and Peter, I wonder if you could elaborate a little bit on the rate environment out there right now what you are all seeing?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Peter, Brian. The rate environment you need to take geographical locations, as well as segments of business. And what we've seen in the third quarter is less of a headwind, so I'd say it's been flat to slightly down in our overall portfolio.
componenttext: Sure. This is Peter, Brian. The rate environment you need to take geographical locations, as well as segments of business. And what we've seen in the third quarter is less of a headwind, so I'd say it's been flat to slightly down in our overall portfolio. Our peak zones, as well as property is starting to firm a little bit more, but I would say low- to mid-single digits. You've seen in the U.S. some modest increase of workers' compensation. Having said that, casualty and professional lines we still see rate decreases year-over-year. Then we look across the world in other parts of Europe, it still remains flat to down. And again on the peak zones, perhaps like New Zealand and Japan, we're seeing some price increases on property. So it's less of a headwind for us than it was a year ago today, but still I would say it's moderate to -- flat to moderate.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Pretty similar to what Peter said, essentially it varies by geography on the cat zone. We've seen in the U.S. Canada 5% to 10%. Obviously, Japan major increases of the cat side. The rest, pretty flat. There's been excess capital in the market, despite dif
componenttext: Pretty similar to what Peter said, essentially it varies by geography on the cat zone. We've seen in the U.S. Canada 5% to 10%. Obviously, Japan major increases of the cat side. The rest, pretty flat. There's been excess capital in the market, despite different influences from modeling and interest rates and macroeconomic and inflation and so on. We're not advocates of increased rates. We're trying to get the best deals of our clients, but we still feel it's hard to gauge the impact going forward.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Larry Greenberg from Langdon
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Larry Greenberg from Langdon

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you might be able to help us with the impact of foreign exchange on the Risk and Insurance Services margin. And then I think Dan mentioned that you have some severance in there as well. If it's possible to give us some color on that.
componenttext: Just wondering if you might be able to help us with the impact of foreign exchange on the Risk and Insurance Services margin. And then I think Dan mentioned that you have some severance in there as well. If it's possible to give us some color on that.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. First on the foreign exchange, foreign exchange was neutral on our NOI and the Risk and Insurance Services. But just mathematically, if it's neutral in the NOI line, then it's going to have a drag in your margins. So we don't want to really give you
componenttext: Sure. First on the foreign exchange, foreign exchange was neutral on our NOI and the Risk and Insurance Services. But just mathematically, if it's neutral in the NOI line, then it's going to have a drag in your margins. So we don't want to really give you any more color than that. And on the severance front, we're not going to break out what the drag in the margin was. But I think the performance in the margin expansion in our segment is pretty impressive barring the FX, the severance and the pension expense.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then just on the rate environment, appreciated the comments on the pricing piece of it, but is there any more color you might be able to provide what's going on, if anything, with terms and conditions? We've heard from some that the
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then just on the rate environment, appreciated the comments on the pricing piece of it, but is there any more color you might be able to provide what's going on, if anything, with terms and conditions? We've heard from some that the excess and surplus lines market is seeing changes with higher retentions limits some of the standard guys moving away. Any color perhaps, Peter, that you can provide on that?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. There's not a trend per se on what is that DNS market or other terms and conditions getting significantly tighter. I think we've seen through the third quarter releases from insurance companies that we have seen probably a little bit more discipline
componenttext: Sure. There's not a trend per se on what is that DNS market or other terms and conditions getting significantly tighter. I think we've seen through the third quarter releases from insurance companies that we have seen probably a little bit more discipline in the market in terms of looking at, again, each segment and each line of business and where they think they need rate. So there's different perspectives a lost cause and what's happening with inflation. And I think you'll see more of a reaction to that than tighter terms and conditions in the EMS market. So I think there really is no specific trend that we saw in the third quarter or that we see really happening in the beginning of the fourth quarter.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Meyer Shields with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Meyer Shields with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me start with a couple of numerical questions if icon. Both investment income and corporate expenses improved sequentially, I was wonder if you have anything unusual in that or whether it's third quarter run rate?
componenttext: Let me start with a couple of numerical questions if icon. Both investment income and corporate expenses improved sequentially, I was wonder if you have anything unusual in that or whether it's third quarter run rate?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, let me take them in pieces. Investment income is separate from fiduciary funds. So when the investment income, we report that on Meyer and that is invested by a third-party. So we don't have good insight -- we've given you the fourth quarter indicat
componenttext: Sure, let me take them in pieces. Investment income is separate from fiduciary funds. So when the investment income, we report that on Meyer and that is invested by a third-party. So we don't have good insight -- we've given you the fourth quarter indication based on the third quarter as we reported. But we don't have any insight as to where that has from a run rate perspective.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll focus more on the fiduciary funds.
componenttext: I'll focus more on the fiduciary funds.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the fiduciary funds, it did improve this quarter. And those are funds the manage on behalf of clients. We've been in this bizarre, near 0 interest rate environments. And we do invest those funds within very narrow and strict policy range to make sure t
componenttext: On the fiduciary funds, it did improve this quarter. And those are funds the manage on behalf of clients. We've been in this bizarre, near 0 interest rate environments. And we do invest those funds within very narrow and strict policy range to make sure that they're highly liquid, et cetera, it did improve. But I think tracking -- your best indicator there is tracking the overall global interest rate. So we have some volatility in the third quarter that actually benefited us, but rates are back down. Your corporate spreads are up a little bit, which you saw the benefit in the third quarter. And kind of similar to our pension discussion, calling interest rate is not what we want to do. So I would use your best use as the run rate percentage there. And the last part on corporate expenses, you asked for a run rate there. And if you look, there are fluctuations for the quarter based on investments that we're making and particularly we have some changes in the second quarter with welcoming Diane to the corporate center. But I think if you look over the last several years, we have been at about $40 million a quarter for corporate expenses, and that's a decent run rate to use.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if can follow-up real quickly. I know you got permission in 2010 to reflect contingents. And I was wondering if it helped play a role in 2012 compared to 2011? Or is everything already fully up and running?
componenttext: And if can follow-up real quickly. I know you got permission in 2010 to reflect contingents. And I was wondering if it helped play a role in 2012 compared to 2011? Or is everything already fully up and running?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would think broadly about carrier revenue streams. So when we look at revenue in general, we're looking at negotiating fee increases where we can with our client base. Then when we look at the value that we're adding to carriers, we negotiate where we c
componenttext: I would think broadly about carrier revenue streams. So when we look at revenue in general, we're looking at negotiating fee increases where we can with our client base. Then when we look at the value that we're adding to carriers, we negotiate where we can higher commission levels what we call yields. Then we look at areas of the fee for services or enhanced commission based upon helping carriers become more efficient. And then we have that minor bit of contingent income, which is largely in the Marsh & McLennan Agency and in some parts of our business where we're actually in MGA. Overall, the negotiation that we have with carriers about levels of income we might receive is about the value that we're providing them. And so that's a continual discussion, it's not something that will stop. That's an every year thing. And we're building up our capabilities to add more and more value, so we think that we will be able to drive more carrier revenue over time on a multiyear basis

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Michael from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Michael from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about progress within MMC agency and initiatives this quarter?
componenttext: Could you talk about progress within MMC agency and initiatives this quarter?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: With Marsh & McLennan Agency, we talked about this last quarter as well, we feel very comfortable where we are about $300 million of revenue in the Marsh & McLennan Agency, very strong pipeline as we continue to expand on our strategy. There's no time fra
componenttext: With Marsh & McLennan Agency, we talked about this last quarter as well, we feel very comfortable where we are about $300 million of revenue in the Marsh & McLennan Agency, very strong pipeline as we continue to expand on our strategy. There's no time frame in terms of when we want to build it out. We look at the high-quality assets to add in to our organization. We think we're probably underweight a little bit in the middle market space, so we think there's a lot of opportunity to expand. And from a financial standpoint, we're on target in terms of growth and earnings and believe it will be accretive in the second year, which is a threshold recent for our acquisitions. So overall, we are very pleased.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I do have a follow-up. Just mentioning 10% operating earnings growth and the expectation there, I know Vanessa you mentioned you won't talk about rates and effect on pension expense, but just kind of given where we are now, is that a goal that you feel li
componenttext: I do have a follow-up. Just mentioning 10% operating earnings growth and the expectation there, I know Vanessa you mentioned you won't talk about rates and effect on pension expense, but just kind of given where we are now, is that a goal that you feel like in this environment is still obtainable in the near-term?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a long-term goal, and long-term goals you don't get there without going through the near-term. The answer is, yes, we believe it's obtainable.
componenttext: It's a long-term goal, and long-term goals you don't get there without going through the near-term. The answer is, yes, we believe it's obtainable.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jay Gelb from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jay Gelb from Barclays Capital.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. First in terms of the potential for margin expansion, I realize there's a number of non-core drag items on margin improvement. But given the strong organic growth profile for revenues, when do you think we'll start seeing it comes t
componenttext: Two questions for you. First in terms of the potential for margin expansion, I realize there's a number of non-core drag items on margin improvement. But given the strong organic growth profile for revenues, when do you think we'll start seeing it comes through in the Risk and Insurance Services?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about this segment overall. And again, I think margin expansion, private growth the margin expansion is both what we're focused on. So when we look at it we're in the height of budget season right now, planning for next year in looking at our
componenttext: Let me talk about this segment overall. And again, I think margin expansion, private growth the margin expansion is both what we're focused on. So when we look at it we're in the height of budget season right now, planning for next year in looking at our plans over a number of years, management's drive is how do we create possible growth for the organization. And we're very comfortable with our strategic positioning, the quality of colleagues we believe in the industry needs the insurance business in the risk and insurance segment. And so when we look at it, we look at it as each year. We would expect to be able to expand our margins and have a profitable growth. Now the fact that we have some advance, we've already far gotten some ways, the fiduciary income. And since it came up earlier in the call, that is a significant amount of money that would eventually someday roll back into our RIS and in particularly into Marsh. But we've been managing well through those headwinds, and we will continue to do that. So we will operate as business as long as we can keep expense growth underneath revenue growth, we will be able to grow profit and improve our margin.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then for Brian on the pricing side, I'm trying to get your perspective on where do you see the current pace of price improvement particularly in the U.S. Is this similar to a 1999 and early 2000 level where you some positive ways of improving rates ov
componenttext: And then for Brian on the pricing side, I'm trying to get your perspective on where do you see the current pace of price improvement particularly in the U.S. Is this similar to a 1999 and early 2000 level where you some positive ways of improving rates over time and continue to build momentum?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll tell you, it's tough to make calls.I've been through a few of these cycles, not too many because we have too many markets. And the strange thing is there all different. They all start out for different reasons, going to different directions. It
componenttext: Well, I'll tell you, it's tough to make calls.I've been through a few of these cycles, not too many because we have too many markets. And the strange thing is there all different. They all start out for different reasons, going to different directions. It is very hard to say, yes, this is exactly like '99 things are so much different in '99 today the economically, globally, all that. I would say one of the issues with that period was kind of an exhaustion that took place, that's the word I've been using, and there was just nowhere else to go with rates expect to back up. And that is the real question that we reached that point. I think you heard from Peter and from Dan and from Alex that there isn't a real pattern necessarily for forming yet here, some ups and downs, some sideways, nothing dramatic either way. And so I think this is going to have its own characteristics and your call is as good as mine when this all changes. And one day, we'll have answer. That's what's great about it.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Adam Klauber from William Blair.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Adam Klauber from William Blair.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: EMEA was clearly a strong point for the quarter. At some point, did that get impacted by the weakness in Europe?
componenttext: EMEA was clearly a strong point for the quarter. At some point, did that get impacted by the weakness in Europe?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: It really looks at what segment you're looking at. I think the segment or the area where we would have the most exposure is in Consulting and specifically within Oliver Wyman and then the FS space. That would be we're at would that most likely come from.
componenttext: It really looks at what segment you're looking at. I think the segment or the area where we would have the most exposure is in Consulting and specifically within Oliver Wyman and then the FS space. That would be we're at would that most likely come from. We are not seeing right now, impacts with regard to the turmoil in Europe in either our Risk and Insurance Services segment or in Mercer. Logic would tell that probably we would see it first, but we're not seeing that right now.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And one follow-up, Mercer have strong underlying revenue growth. Is that coming more from new clients, or more work at existing clients?
componenttext: And one follow-up, Mercer have strong underlying revenue growth. Is that coming more from new clients, or more work at existing clients?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The answer to that is, it's always a mix. Mercer has actually very strong new business development over the past couple of years. And so that's certainly a big part of their growth particularly in areas where we have invested around the world such as Heal
componenttext: The answer to that is, it's always a mix. Mercer has actually very strong new business development over the past couple of years. And so that's certainly a big part of their growth particularly in areas where we have invested around the world such as Health and Benefits. If you look at Mercer piece by piece, this most significant area of growth have been Rewards, Talent and Communications Health and Benefits and the investment space. And so all of those areas are actually doing quite well. I'll just take a moment our Rewards, Talent and Communications because they've had a fifth consecutive quarter of double-digit growth. And really, the core bread-and-butter rewards business is very strong across all regions, that includes consulting and data. The compensation survey business again, demand is up across all regions. And it's high demand for talent management, specifically leadership development and skills assessment in emerging markets. So we're very well-positioned to capture that trend. And I think at this stage, 5 quarters in a row, you would see that as a trend.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from Thomas Pilcher from Miller Tabak.
componenttext: And our final question comes from Thomas Pilcher from Miller Tabak.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just noticing the cost of living seems to be rising. Our interest rates have stayed very, very low. I'm wondering if this environment is creating challenges for companies that would create new opportunities for your Retirement and employee benefits busine
componenttext: Just noticing the cost of living seems to be rising. Our interest rates have stayed very, very low. I'm wondering if this environment is creating challenges for companies that would create new opportunities for your Retirement and employee benefits business there I'm wondering is this more sort of a broad picture, looking at over the next 3 to 5 years. Do these factors make a difference or not?

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: They absolutely make a difference because clients need advise. And when you see changes in the macro environment, when you see legislative change, then that heightens the need for advise. When we look at our business whether it's healthcare, legislation o
componenttext: They absolutely make a difference because clients need advise. And when you see changes in the macro environment, when you see legislative change, then that heightens the need for advise. When we look at our business whether it's healthcare, legislation or healthcare delivery changes around the world, our retirement as an issue -- retirement, we don't expect that retirement is a declining business. We know that their revenue has been in decline for the last number of quarters last year and this year. But fundamentally, we believe clients need solutions and that we are very well-positioned to invent solutions and innovate for our clients. And so we're working hard doing that now.

I think one, our business is generally a B2B and also B2B2C, so we're not really in B2C directs based on things like annuities are for life insurance sales. We're talking to companies. Our dialogue with life insurance companies is around. We all believe that annuities provide part of the answer and perhaps even annuities lead to long-term care of our interesting products and all of our surprise the lack of take out so there's a lot of interest around greater product in annuity kind of format. And for companies to look at how they can support that for their calling base, particularly as they move from DB to DC. But the life insurance companies themselves have said they're not a tremendous the active market.
so let me close by thanking 52,000 employees. They have delivered another outstanding quarter, and I'm grateful to you for all that you do, your dedication and commitment to drive the company forward. And I'm honored to serve as your CEO. Thank you, everybody, and goodbye

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marsh & McLennan Companies Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Third quarter 2011 financial results and supplemental information were issued earlier this morning. They are available on Marsh & McLennan Companies' website at www
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marsh & McLennan Companies Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. Third quarter 2011 financial results and supplemental information were issued earlier this morning. They are available on Marsh & McLennan Companies' website at www.mmc.com.
Before we begin, I would like remind you that remarks made today may include statements relating to future events or results, which are forward-looking statements as that term is defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements are subject to inherent risks and uncertainties. In particular, references during this conference call to anticipated or expected results of operations for 2011 or subsequent periods are forward-looking statements, and Marsh & McLennan Companies' actual results may be affected by a variety of factors. Please refer to Marsh & McLennan Companies' most recent SEC filings, as well as the company's earnings release, which are available on the Marsh & McLennan Companies' website, for additional information on factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements made today. 
I'll now turn this call over to Brian Duperreault, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Please go ahead.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our third quarter results as reported earlier today. I'm Brian Duperreault, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining me on the call today is Dan Glaser, Group President and COO; and Van
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us to discuss our third quarter results as reported earlier today. I'm Brian Duperreault, President and CEO of Marsh & McLennan Companies. Joining me on the call today is Dan Glaser, Group President and COO; and Vanessa Wittman, our CFO. Also, I'd like to welcome our operating companies CEOs: Peter Zaffino of Marsh; Alex Moczarski of Guy Carpenter; and John Drzik of Oliver Wyman. Also with us is Mike Bischoff. 
Following my comments, Dan will discuss our operating results in more detail. Vanessa will then update you on our financial position. 
Before we begin our discussions of the third quarter, I'd like to take a moment to recognize and thank Michele Burns for her many contributions to our company over the last 5 years. Michele became Mercer’s CEO in 2006 and led Mercer through a period of growth despite severe turbulence in the global economy. Last month, we announced that Michele has accepted a new role: to build and lead a retirement policy center. I believe this center has the potential of making a major contribution for finding solutions that address the retirement issues facing the United States. I'm excited that Michele has agreed to take on the challenge of leading this effort. We are now searching for a new CEO of Mercer, and until a successor is named, Dan will be overseeing Mercer’s operations. 
Now let's move to our third quarter results, which reflect our ongoing strong performance. We generated revenue growth of 11%. On an underlying basis, revenue growth was 5%, and we continue to achieve this growth while maintaining effective control over our operating expenses. This led to an increase in operating income of 30% and growth in adjusted operating income of 18%. 
Let's turn to our operating companies. The positive momentum at Marsh continued this quarter, with underlying revenue growth across all geographies driven by higher client revenue retention rates and new business development. Guy Carpenter also generated impressive results, continuing its trend of producing quarterly underlying revenue growth, which has extended over the past 3 years. Mercer produced underlying revenue growth of mid-single digits as it has over the past year. Oliver Wyman's strong revenue growth continued reflecting broad-based growth across its major industry sectors. So throughout Marsh & McLennan Companies, we've seen revenue increases and higher levels of profitability. 
This record of performance is very much in keeping with the goals we articulated at Investor Day in September of 2010. It's now been more than a year since then, so I think it's appropriate to step back and look at the progress the company has made. We're implementing our plan to establish Marsh & McLennan Companies as an elite, global growth company, valued by clients, our colleagues and shareholders. We articulated a strategy focusing on 4 pillars: growth in revenue and earnings per share, low capital requirements, high cash generation and reducing the risk profile of the company. 
As you look at our performance since Investor Day, the achievements are evident. Over the last 4 quarters, the company has produced underlying revenue growth of 5%, and I'm pleased that each of the operating companies contributed to that achievement. Marsh grew by 5%; Carpenter, 5%; Mercer, 4%; and Oliver Wyman grew 9%. Our goal is to produce underlying revenue growth, while maintaining expense discipline, thereby generating at least 10% organic growth and adjusted operating income over the long term. 
I'm pleased to report that we are achieving our goals. We have produced revenue growth across the entire enterprise. We have continued to make investments for future growth. And we've done this by limiting -- while limiting our adjusted underlying expense growth to 4%. As a result, I'm very pleased that over the last 4 quarters, Marsh & McLennan Companies generated organic growth in adjusted operating income of 13%, an outstanding performance. This earnings growth, combined with our dividend yield of 3%, is a very attractive result for our investors and in keeping with the goals we articulated at Investor Day more than a year ago. 
Additionally, we've continued to maintain low capital requirements and generate high levels of cash. Operational changes throughout the organization, we believe, have lowered the companies risk profile. Our financial position has strengthened during this period as well, which Vanessa will discuss in a few minutes. 
As we move forward, we remain committed to focusing on profitable growth and prudent redeployment of our excess cash flow in order to produce outstanding long-term returns for our shareholders. 
With that, let me turn it over to Dan to review our third quarter results in more detail.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Marsh & McLennan Companies continued its strong performance in the third quarter. We generated underlying revenue growth that have paced consistent with prior periods with impressive growth in both operating i
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Marsh & McLennan Companies continued its strong performance in the third quarter. We generated underlying revenue growth that have paced consistent with prior periods with impressive growth in both operating income and adjusted operating income. 
Let me go into a little more detail on our operating results. In the third quarter, we achieved revenue growth and increased adjusted operating income at each of our operating companies as we have for each quarter over the past year. In the quarter, revenue rose 11% to $2.8 billion, while underlying revenue growth was 5%. Adjusted operating income increased 18%. 
Risk and Insurance Services revenue was up 11% to $1.5 billion, with underlying revenue growth of 5%. And with ongoing effective expense management, adjusted operating income increased 13% to $186 million. The adjusted operating margin increased 20 basis points, reflecting slightly higher margins at both of Marsh and Guy Carpenter. This is also indicative of the segment's performance year-to-date where the margin has increased to 19.5% despite the effects of higher pension expense. 
Marsh had another strong quarter. Revenue increased 12% to $1.2 billion. Underlying revenue rose 6%. Marsh's high client revenue retention rate and new business development produced underlying revenue growth across all geographies, led by strong growth in Asia Pacific and Latin America of 13%. In the U.S./Canada division, underlying revenue growth was 3% for the fifth consecutive quarter. Marsh has maintained its disciplined expense control, while still being able to invest in the future, refine its operating model and absorb higher severance and pension expense. As a result, Marsh produced double-digit growth in adjusted operating income, not just for the quarter, but the year-to-date as well. 
In August, we announced a significant expansion of our South African operations with the signing of an agreement to acquire the insurance broking business of Alexander Forbes. The transaction is scheduled to close by year end. 
Now turning to reinsurance broking. Guy Carpenter continued to produce strong results. Revenue increased 8% to $251 million with underlying growth of 3%. This growth was led by its international operations, reflecting the successful execution of its long-term business strategy. Over the last 3 years, Carpenter has consistently produced quarterly underlying revenue growth. It has been able to accomplish this through strong new business development and high client retention. 
So in summary, both March and Guy Carpenter produced strong financial results, not only in the third quarter, but for the 9 months as well. 
Turning to our Consulting segment. Our operations continued to generate strong revenue growth. In the third quarter, revenue rose 11% to $1.3 billion with underlying growth of 6%. Growth in adjusted underlying expenses was 5%, which resulted in a 50 basis point increase in the adjusted operating margin for the quarter. Growth in adjusted operating income was 17%, not only for the third quarter, but for the year as well, with both Mercer and Oliver Wyman contributing to this strong growth. 
Mercer continued the solid performance we have seen over the past year. Revenue in the third quarter increased 11% to $975 million, and underlying revenue growth was 4%, with all geographic regions contributing to this growth. Consistent with the revenue trends we have seen in Mercer’s lines of business over the past year, retirement saw underlying revenue decline modestly. Health and benefits had a fine performance with an underlying increase of 7%, driven by strong growth in the U.S. and Asia Pacific. Rewards, talent & communications produced double-digit underlying revenue growth for the fifth consecutive quarter. Outsourcing generated underlying growth of 1%, reflecting growth in Asia Pacific, partially offset by a decline in the United States. And investment consulting & management produced underlying growth of 10% with strong growth in the U.S. and EMEA. 
Oliver Wyman also had a good quarter with an increase in revenue of 13%. Underlying revenue growth was 9%. This growth was diversified with the strongest growth coming from the health care and consumer industry sectors. Oliver Wyman's expense management also contributed to a solid increase in adjusted operating income. 
In summary, we are very pleased with the excellent performance of each of our operating companies, not only this quarter but throughout the entire year, both from a revenue and earnings growth standpoint. 
Now let me make several comments regarding how the increased economic uncertainty that developed in mid-summer, particularly in Europe, may impact our near-term results. Oliver Wyman is our most economically sensitive operating company. We have seen some clients in the financial services sector defer decisions on new engagements, thus making it difficult for Oliver Wyman to generate growth in the fourth quarter, resulting in a modest impact on the segment's profitability. Currently, overall client interest remains high and the pipeline going into 2012 looks encouraging. However, there is a high degree of uncertainty. So that's 0W. 
At Mercer, all signs indicate that the positive trends experienced in the first 9 months of the year are continuing and we feel that any near-term economic uncertainty is not impacting our Risk and Insurance Services segment. So notwithstanding near-term economic issues, we believe we are on target to have a very successful year and remain optimistic as we develop our strategy and business plans for 2012. 
With that, let me turn it over to Vanessa.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan, and good morning, everyone. As you've heard, the strong financial performance of Marsh & McLennan Companies continued in the third quarter. On a GAAP basis, net income was $130 million or $0.24 per share. Adjusted earnings per share was al
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan, and good morning, everyone. As you've heard, the strong financial performance of Marsh & McLennan Companies continued in the third quarter. On a GAAP basis, net income was $130 million or $0.24 per share. Adjusted earnings per share was also $0.24. Costs of $72 million related to the early extinguishment of debt from the tender offer are highlighted on a separate line in this quarter's income statement. This expense is reflected in both our GAAP EPS and our adjusted EPS. I should also note that our a GAAP and adjusted earnings are almost identical for the 9-month period as well. Operating income totaled $1.247 billion, and adjusted operating income was $1.252 billion. As a result, GAAP earnings per share from continuing operations year-to-date was $1.30 and adjusted earnings per share also totaled $1.30. 
Now let me add some color regarding other items, including our recent financing activities. In the third quarter, interest expense decreased to $49 million from $60 million a year ago. This level of quarterly interest expense is a reasonable indicator of the run rate we expect going forward. Several actions taken over the past 12 months substantially reduced our interest expense. First was the payment of a $550 million debt obligation in September 2010. Next, in July of this year, we took advantage of the interest rate environment through a tender refinancing effort to  extend our maturity ladder and reduce our aggregate interest expense. We had $1.4 billion of debt coming due in 2014 and 2015, and we successfully tendered for $600 million of these bonds. We funded the tender with $100 million dollars of cash and a new 10-year note for $500 million with a coupon of 4.8%. We are very pleased with these transactions, which allowed us to opportunistically refine our capital structure, lower our refinancing risks in the intermediate term, extend maturities of our debt portfolio at a very attractive interest rate and delever our balance sheet. In total, the actions taken over the past year reduced our annual interest expense by $45 million. 
Turning to investment income. In the third quarter, investment income was essentially 0 compared with a $2 million loss in last year's third quarter. Due to a decline in the equity markets in the third quarter, we anticipate reporting an investment loss of approximately $10 million in the fourth quarter. 
Moving on to share repurchase. Since beginning our share repurchase program in last year's fourth quarter, the company has repurchased a total of 15.6 million shares at a cost of $447 million, including 4.4 million shares that were purchased in the third quarter. In August, our Board of Directors authorized an increase in the share repurchase program to $1 billion from $500 million. 
Looking at taxes. Our adjusted tax rate this quarter increased to 32.7%. This compares with 30.4% in last year's third quarter. A drop in the U.K. statutory tax rate reduced the value of our U.K. net deferred tax assets, which was fully reflected this quarter. This change in the U.K. tax law put upward pressure on our adjusted tax rate in the third quarter but will slightly benefit our overall tax position going forward. 
The higher tax rate in the current quarter also reflects a slight shift in the geographic mix of earnings. While there may be volatility in our tax rate from quarter-to-quarter, we still feel that for modeling purposes, it is reasonable to assume a tax rate of approximately 31% over the next year. 
Due to our high cash generation, we were able to redeploy our cash in the third quarter in a number of ways, including a $126 million per share repurchase, $123 million for dividends, $100 million to reduce long-term debt, $72 million for the early debt repayment and $21 million for acquisitions. This effective redeployment of capital will also contribute to our future growth in earnings per share. And despite all of these actions, our cash position increased $55 million during the third quarter. 
Debt at the end of the third quarter was $2.9 billion. We have a $250 million note due March 15, 2012, which is our only debt coming due in 2012. 
Last month, we took advantage of favorable conditions in the credit market, and we're able to close a new $1 billion, 5-year revolving credit facility to replace our existing $1 billion, 3-year credit facility that was due to expire next year. We are very pleased with the increased financial flexibility and reduced uncertainty, resulting from the new facilities' extended duration. 
With that, I'll turn the call back to Brian.

componenttextpreview: I guess first question for Dan, just around Consulting. When I think about your comments about Oliver Wyman going into the fourth quarter, maybe a little bit tougher, it seems. Maybe you could talk about that in the context of the margin. It seems Oliver
componenttext: I guess first question for Dan, just around Consulting. When I think about your comments about Oliver Wyman going into the fourth quarter, maybe a little bit tougher, it seems. Maybe you could talk about that in the context of the margin. It seems Oliver Wyman probably has a lot higher margin with the revenue per head being, I think, double what Mercer is. And if you can kind of also talk in the broader context of just Mercer margins in general. What do you think you can take that to over the next couple of years? It seems your competitors have some much higher target out there although they seem to be going backwards at this point, but if you could talk to that.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'll talk for a while and then John will probably have some comments specific to Oliver Wyman. But in general, we don't disclose margins for individual operating companies. We've talked about this segment overall, and so let me just start there.
componenttext: Okay. So I'll talk for a while and then John will probably have some comments specific to Oliver Wyman. But in general, we don't disclose margins for individual operating companies. We've talked about this segment overall, and so let me just start there. For both Oliver Wyman and Mercer, we believe that, over time, we will be able to expand margins. And so we're very much focused on creating the business disciplines that are necessary in order to be able to commit to that, so that's #1. I'll leave it to John in a second to talk about Oliver Wyman, specifically, and what he's seeing in the market. In terms of Mercer, I'd start by saying, Mercer is a really strong company. It's large. It's growing. It's globally coordinated. It's profitable. It's got some great people. It's got a great client list. So I've spent a good part of my time in the last 5 months really digging into Mercer, and a lot of what I see, I'm pleased with. My goal is to work with the Mercer leadership team to take all of this and make it better. We can be more global. We can be more profitable with better margins. And we can be more innovative. And so that will be the focus of the leadership team and I over the coming months and years.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So Keith, just to expand a bit on what Dan said in his comments about Oliver Wyman. In August and September, when we were in a period there of tightened economic uncertainty and more market volatility, it resulted in a slowdown in new sales for Oliver Wym
componenttext: So Keith, just to expand a bit on what Dan said in his comments about Oliver Wyman. In August and September, when we were in a period there of tightened economic uncertainty and more market volatility, it resulted in a slowdown in new sales for Oliver Wyman. So while our third quarter results were strong with a 9% growth, that will impact our fourth quarter, and so fourth quarter will be weaker. And particularly, financial services sector, especially the banking sector, was where we were experiencing the weakness. And as Dan said, it'll make Q4 challenging one for us. It'll be challenging for us to grow in Q4. Now looking at what recent events mean, in October, sales picked up to back to a normal pace as the market seems stabilized. And client pipeline is encouraging at this point. But obviously, events of this week suggest there could be an extended period of uncertainty and we could see that coming back in. So I think looking at the medium term, I'd say we're very confident that Oliver Wyman is an attractive growth business and will generate margin growth, as Dan said, over that period. But quarter-to-quarter, we could fluctuate somewhat based on the economic outlook and uncertainty. And obviously, that's, I think, what we'll experience in the fourth quarter this year.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011

componenttext: Keith, I believe, last year, the aggregate -- because remember, you've got to look across both the U.S. and the U.K. And on a blended basis, it was about a 40 basis point change, but that's blended. And you've got plans in the U.S. and the U.K. and then the rest of the world where those are individual calcs. And that would have led to our change, which has been about a $12 million per quarter impact over the course of the year.

componenttext: Just taking that and you got about a 50 basis point discount rate reduction year-to-date we're looking at in both the U.S. and the U.K., I would assume the impact in 2012 potentially would be of a similar magnitude, ballpark.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we have said in the past, I know it's tempting at this point in the year and with the volatility that we see in the markets for us to make a call and give you a prediction. But as we've also done in the past, we're not going to give you a prediction. W
componenttext: As we have said in the past, I know it's tempting at this point in the year and with the volatility that we see in the markets for us to make a call and give you a prediction. But as we've also done in the past, we're not going to give you a prediction. We are very keenly focused on the changes, but it's just not right for a public dialogue. And what you can count on, Keith, is that as we have done to date, we will -- we're watching it, we're monitoring it and we'll continue to manage the business through next year to deliver on our commitments to our shareholders.
